title: Chapter 7 bankruptcy & calculatingincome. Due 2retirement accts (I think)my W2 has Gross income then higher # for medicare wages
question: The question is can I use the lower Gross income number from my W2, which is the amount used on my Federal tax return? Or, do I need to account for the higher number listed in my W2 as Medicare Wages.
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy means test,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Employee retirement benefits,Tax return,Representing yourself
answers: The means test is customarily calculated by reference to your last six months pay stubs. One would not use a W-2 for this purpose. BTW - Filing an above means bankruptcy pro se is a very bad idea.

You have to use the gross amount. Nolo.com has a convenient means test calculator that you can use to see if you qualify under the means test. http://www.legalconsumer.com/bankruptcy/nolo/syn_nolo_bankruptcy-means-test.php?ZIP=92648&sponsor=nolo#QuickTest.
Have to use the gross number and number in household. Can't use the number after deductions.

Check with your payroll department to see what the source of the additional "income" is on your total gross. In many instances, the employer adds the cost of medical insurance & other expenses to your gross income, and these expenses are not taxed. If the total gross includes medical insurance, then you would be able to use the smaller amount. But unless you know what the employer is counting as income, you shouldn't guess or just take the chance.

Hope this perspective helps!
